turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Huawei.
turn.1: What are the main reasons for the international boycott of Huawei?
turn.2: Especially with the development of 5G wireless networks (which China has aggressively promoted), there have been calls from the U.S. to prevent the use of products by Huawei or fellow Chinese telecom ZTE by the U.S. or its allies.
turn.3: does huawei agree with the international boycott?
turn.4: Huawei has argued that its products posed "no greater cybersecurity risk" than those of any other vendor and that there is no evidence of the U.S. espionage claims.
turn.5: Are they able to do anything about the boycott?
turn.6: Nonetheless, Huawei pulled out of the U.S. consumer market in 2018, after these concerns affected the ability to market their consumer products there.
turn.7: Is the boycott still in effect?
turn.8: U.S. measures intensified in May 2019; in the midst of an ongoing trade war between China and the United States, Huawei was restricted from doing commerce with U.S. companies due to alleged previous willful violations of U.S. sanctions against Iran.
turn.9: Is anyone doing anything about the boycott?
turn.10: On 29 June 2019, U.S. President Donald Trump reached an agreement to resume trade talks with China and announced that he would ease the aforementioned sanctions on Huawei.
turn.11: Is there anything else interesting about the article?
turn.12: According to the company founder Ren Zhengfei, the name "Huawei" comes from a phrase he saw on a wall, "Zhonghua youwei" meaning "China has promise" (中华有为, "Zhōnghuá yǒuwéi"), when he was starting the company and needed a name.
